x10.mongo.yak
Class YakCollection

x10.lang.Object
  x10.mongo.yak.YakCollection
All Implemented Interfaces:
x10.lang.Any
public class YakCollection
extends x10.lang.Object
implements x10.io.CustomSerialization

The Yak representation of a Mongo collection. Internally, it is a wrapper around a com.mongodb.DBCollection. It has approximately the same interface as one.

X10 Safety of Modification Operations: If you want X10 to be aware of when modification operations (update, insert, save, remove) are finished, you will need to use methods which wait for the server to send back a response.

Accordingly, YakCollections have a default WriteConcern of WriteConcern.SAFE. This differs from the Java Mongo class com.mongodb.DBObject, which uses a weaker default write concern.

Using a WriteConcern argument of WriteConcern.SAFE seems to do fairly well, but occasionally fails in stress tests. Unlike the Java binding for Mongo, the X10 binding takes WriteConcern.SAFE as the default. This means that operations which do not specify an explicit WriteConcern (usually) interact properly with X10's finish construct.

If you need to get around this, you may either call setWriteConcern() on the whole collection, or use modification operations which specify a WriteConcern argument. Query Options Like com.mongodb.DBCollection, a YakCollection has a set of default options which are used for queries. These options can be manipulated by addOption(), setOptions(), resetOptions(), and getOptions(). See com.mongodb.Bytes for the available options.

update


public com.mongodb.WriteResult update(com.mongodb.DBObject query,
                                      com.mongodb.DBObject mod,
                                      x10.lang.Boolean upsert,
                                      x10.lang.Boolean multi,
                                      com.mongodb.WriteConcern concern)




General update operation.
Find one or all (depending on multi) records matching query.  Apply the
modifier mod to them.   If there are none and if upsert is true,
insert a single record, obtained by applying mod to query.
(This may do surprising things if query does more than equality tests on fields.)
Wait for results to be as reliably performed as specified by concern.











Parameters:
query - Search query for which record(s) to update.
mod - Modifier to apply to those records
upsert - Should this be an "upsert" operation? (See Mongo documents)
multi - Should this apply to all records, or just one
concern - What kind of behavior and error reporting should this operation have?










update


public com.mongodb.WriteResult update(com.mongodb.DBObject query,
                                      com.mongodb.DBObject mod,
                                      x10.lang.Boolean upsert,
                                      x10.lang.Boolean a22,
                                      com.mongodb.WriteConcern concern,
                                      com.mongodb.DBEncoder encoder)




General update operation.
Find one or all (depending on multi) records matching query.  Apply the
modifier mod to them.   If there are none and if upsert is true,
insert a single record, obtained by applying mod to query.
(This may do surprising things if query does more than equality tests on fields.)
Wait for results to be as reliably performed as specified by concern.
This uses an encoder.











Parameters:
query - Search query for which record(s) to update.
mod - Modifier to apply to those records
upsert - Should this be an "upsert" operation? (See Mongo documents)
multi - Should this apply to all records, or just one
concern - What kind of behavior and error reporting should this operation have?
encoder - 










update


public com.mongodb.WriteResult update(com.mongodb.DBObject query,
                                      com.mongodb.DBObject mod,
                                      x10.lang.Boolean upsert,
                                      x10.lang.Boolean multi)




Update operation.
Find one or all (depending on multi) records matching query.  Apply the
modifier mod to them.   If there are none and if upsert is true,
insert a single record, obtained by applying mod to query.
(This may do surprising things if query does more than equality tests on fields.)
Wait for results to be as reliably performed as specified by the default write concern,
which is SAFE.
This method works pretty well with X10; see the class introduction
on X10 safety.











Parameters:
query - Search query for which record(s) to update.
mod - Modifier to apply to those records
upsert - Should this be an "upsert" operation? (See Mongo documents)
multi - Should this apply to all records, or just one










update


public com.mongodb.WriteResult update(com.mongodb.DBObject query,
                                      com.mongodb.DBObject mod)




Update operation.
Find one  record matching query.  Apply the modifier mod to it.
It neither upserts nor updates multiple records
Wait for results to be as reliably performed as specified by the default write concern,
which is SAFE.
This method works pretty well with X10; see the class introduction
on X10 safety.











Parameters:
query - Search query for which record(s) to update.
mod - Modifier to apply to those records










updateMulti


public com.mongodb.WriteResult updateMulti(com.mongodb.DBObject query,
                                           com.mongodb.DBObject mod)




Update operation.
Find all records matching query.  Apply the
modifier mod to them.
This is the usual update  operation with
multi=true and upsert=false.
Wait for results to be as reliably performed as specified by the default write concern,
which is SAFE.
This method works pretty well with X10; see the class introduction
on X10 safety.











Parameters:
query - Search query for which record(s) to update.
mod - Modifier to apply to those records

find


public final YakCursor find(com.mongodb.DBObject query,
                            com.mongodb.DBObject fields,
                            x10.lang.Int numToSkip,
                            x10.lang.Int batchSize,
                            x10.lang.Int options)




Returns a cursor iterating over objects matching query.
fields is a BSON object whose fields will appear in the result;
that is, to get only the a and b fields,
use a fields parameter like {a:1,b:1}.











Parameters:
query - Query that found objects will match.
fields - Fields appearing in result.
numToSkip - Number of records to skip before the first one returned.
batchSize - Maximum number of records to return
options - - Further options, which should be a sum of static fields of com.mongodb.Bytes, of the form QUERYOPTION_
.

findAndModify


public YakMap findAndModify(com.mongodb.DBObject query,
                            com.mongodb.DBObject fields,
                            com.mongodb.DBObject sort,
                            x10.lang.Boolean remove,
                            com.mongodb.DBObject mod,
                            x10.lang.Boolean returnNew,
                            x10.lang.Boolean upsert)




Find the first document in sort order matching query, and apply mod as an update modifier to it.











Parameters:
query - Query to match
fields - Fields to be returned, or null if all fields are to be returned.
sort - Sort criterion to apply when picking which document is first, or null not to sort.
remove - If true, the document found will be removed.
mod - Update modifier to apply
returnNew - If true, return the updated document; otherwise, return the original un-updated one.

getCount


public x10.lang.Long getCount(com.mongodb.DBObject query,
                              com.mongodb.DBObject fields)




Returns the number of documents matching query.
This is a copy of a method from the Java implementation,
which calls getCount(query,fields,0L,0L).
Despite fields being documented (as in Java) as "fields to return",
getCount() returns a long, not any fields.

query - query to match
fields - fields to return.

rename


public YakCollection rename(x10.lang.String newName,
                            x10.lang.Boolean dropExistingCollectionWithThatName)




Renames this collection to newName, controlling what to do if that name is in use.
If a collection of that name already exists, the behavior depends on
the flag dropExistingCollectionWithThatName.
If dropExistingCollectionWithThatName is true, the existing collection is deleted.
If it is false, an exception is thrown.











Parameters:
newName - The new name
dropExistingCollectionWithThatName - What to do in case of error.










group


public YakMap group(com.mongodb.DBObject key,
                    com.mongodb.DBObject cond,
                    com.mongodb.DBObject initial,
                    x10.lang.String reducer,
                    x10.lang.String finalizer)




A Mongo group operation, analogous to SQL's GROUP BY operation.
This function maintains an aggregation counter object,
initialized to initial,
updated by the Javascript function reduce for each record in the group
and tidied up by the Javascript function finalizer afterwards.
See the Mongo documentation for details.











Parameters:
key - A BSON object whose field names are the keys to group by. (In the Mongo examples, the associates values are always true. This may be significant.)
cond - A query; only the values which satisfy cond are grouped.
initial - The initial value of the aggregation counter object.
reducer - A string holding a Javascript function function(obj,prev){...} taking the current record as obj and the previous aggregation counter as prev.
finalizer - A string holding a Javascript function function(finalCounter){...} taking the final value of the aggregation counter.
See Also:
http://www.mongodb.org/display/DOCS/Aggregation










group


public com.mongodb.DBObject group(com.mongodb.DBObject key,
                                  com.mongodb.DBObject cond,
                                  com.mongodb.DBObject initial,
                                  x10.lang.String reducer)




A Mongo group operation, analogous to SQL's GROUP BY operation.
This function maintains an aggregation counter object,
initialized to initial,
updated by the Javascript function reduce for each record in the group.
See the Mongo documentation for details.











Parameters:
key - A BSON object whose field names are the keys to group by. (In the Mongo examples, the associates values are always true. This may be significant.)
cond - A query; only the values which satisfy cond are grouped.
initial - The initial value of the aggregation counter object.
reducer - A string holding a Javascript function function(obj,prev){...} taking the current record as obj and the previous aggregation counter as prev.
See Also:
http://www.mongodb.org/display/DOCS/Aggregation

x10$mongo$yak$YakCollection$$x10$mongo$yak$YakCollection$this


public final YakCollection x10$mongo$yak$YakCollection$$x10$mongo$yak$YakCollection$this()




Declaration: x10$mongo$yak$YakCollection$$x10$mongo$yak$YakCollection$this(): x10.mongo.yak.YakCollection{self==this(:x10.mongo.yak.YakCollection)}.
The Yak representation of a Mongo collection.
Internally, it is a wrapper around a com.mongodb.DBCollection.
It has approximately the same interface as one.




 X10 Safety of Modification Operations:
If you want X10 to be aware of when modification operations
(update, insert, save, remove)
are finished, you will need to use methods which wait for the
server to send back a response.


Accordingly, YakCollections have a default WriteConcern
of WriteConcern.SAFE.    This differs from the Java Mongo
class com.mongodb.DBObject, which uses a weaker default write concern.


Using a WriteConcern argument of WriteConcern.SAFE
seems to do fairly well, but occasionally fails in stress tests.
Unlike the Java binding for Mongo, the X10 binding takes
WriteConcern.SAFE as the default.  This means that operations
which do not specify an explicit WriteConcern (usually)
interact properly with X10's finish construct.


If you need to get around this, you may either call setWriteConcern() on
the whole collection, or use modification operations which specify a WriteConcern
argument.
 Query Options
Like com.mongodb.DBCollection, a YakCollection has
a set of default options which are used for queries.  These options
can be manipulated by addOption(), setOptions(),
resetOptions(), and getOptions().
See com.mongodb.Bytes for the available options.
